query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Forse semilia miglia di lontano 2 ci ferve l’ora sesta, e questo mondo 3 china già l’ombra quasi al letto piano,
4 quando ’l mezzo del cielo, a noi profondo, 5 comincia a farsi tal, ch’alcuna stella 6 perde il parere infino a questo fondo;
7 e come vien la chiarissima ancella 8 del sol più oltre, così ’l ciel si chiude 9 di vista in vista infino a la più bella.

Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Non altrimenti il trïunfo che lude 11 sempre dintorno al punto che mi vinse, 12 parendo inchiuso da quel ch’elli ’nchiude,
13 a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse: 14 per che tornar con li occhi a Bëatrice 15 nulla vedere e amor mi costrinse.
query.result:
10 Not otherwise the triumph that praises 11 always around the point that defeated me, 12 seeming enclosed by that which it encloses,
13 little by little to my seeing it faded: 14 for which to return with the eyes to Beatrice 15 nothing to see and love forced me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
16 Se quanto infino a qui di lei si dice 17 fosse conchiuso tutto in una loda, 18 poca sarebbe a fornir questa vice.
query.result: 16 If all that up to here about her is said 17 were enclosed all in one praise, 18 little would be to provide this vice

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 La bellezza ch’io vidi si trasmoda 20 non pur di là da noi, ma certo io credo 21 che solo il suo fattor tutta la goda.
query.result: 19 The beauty that I saw transforms 20 not only beyond us, but certainly I believe 21 that only its maker enjoys it all

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Da questo passo vinto mi concedo 23 più che già mai da punto di suo tema 24 soprato fosse comico o tragedo:
25 ché, come sole in viso che più trema, 26 così lo rimembrar del dolce riso 27 la mente mia da me medesmo scema.
query.result:
22 From this step, won, I grant myself 23 more than ever before from the point of its theme 24 whether it were comic or tragic it would have been surpassed:
25 for, as sun in the face that more trembles, 26 thus the remembering of the sweet laugh 27 my mind by me myself grows foolish.

28 From the first day that I saw his face 29 in this life, up to this sight, 30 it is not to me to follow my precise song;
31 but now it is necessary that my following cease 32 further behind his beauty, poetizing, 33 as to his last each artist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Cotal qual io lascio a maggior bando 35 che quel de la mia tuba, che deduce 36 l’ardüa sua matera terminando,
37 con atto e voce di spedito duce 38 ricominciò: «Noi siamo usciti fore 39 del maggior corpo al ciel ch’è pura luce:
40 luce intellettüal, piena d’amore; 41 amor di vero ben, pien di letizia; 42 letizia che trascende ogne dolzore.
query.result:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Qui vederai l’una e l’altra milizia 44 di paradiso, e l’una in quelli aspetti 45 che tu vedrai a l’ultima giustizia».
query.result: 43 Here you will see the one and the other militia 44 of paradise, and the one in those aspects 45 that you will see at the last justice”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Come sùbito lampo che discetti 47 li spiriti visivi, sì che priva 48 da l’atto l’occhio di più forti obietti,
49 così mi circunfulse luce viva, 50 e lasciommi fasciato di tal velo 51 del suo fulgor, che nulla m’appariva.
query.result:
46 Like a sudden flash that you discovered 47 the visual spirits, so that it deprives 48 from the act the eye of stronger objects,
49 Thus a living light surrounded me, 50 and left me wrapped in such a veil 51 of its brilliance, that nothing appeared to me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 «Sempre l’amor che queta questo cielo 53 accoglie in sé con sì fatta salute, 54 per far disposto a sua fiamma il candelo».
query.result: 52 Always the love that quiets this sky 53 receives within itself with so made health, 54 to make disposed to its flame the candle

64 From such a river came out living sparks, 65 and from every side they set themselves in the flowers, 66 as ruby that gold surrounds;
67 then, as intoxicated by the odors, 68 they deepened themselves in the wonderful gush, 69 and one entered, another exited out.

70 «The high desire that now inflames you and urges, 71 to have news of that which you see, 72 so much I like it more the more it burns;
73 but of this water you must drink 74 before such thirst in you is satisfied»: 75 thus the sun of my eyes said to me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Anche soggiunse: «Il fiume e li topazi 77 ch’entrano ed escono e ’l rider de l’erbe 78 son di lor vero umbriferi prefazi.
query.result: 76 Also added: «The river and the topazes 77 that enter and exit and the laughter of the herbs 78 are of their true shadow‑bearing prefaces.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Non che da sé sian queste cose acerbe; 80 ma è difetto da la parte tua, 81 che non hai viste ancor tanto superbe».

Please translate each line literally into English.
82 Non è fantin che sì sùbito rua 83 col volto verso il latte, se si svegli 84 molto tardato da l’usanza sua,
85 come fec’ io, per far migliori spegli 86 ancor de li occhi, chinandomi a l’onda 87 che si deriva perché vi s’immegli;
88 e sì come di lei bevve la gronda 89 de le palpebre mie, così mi parve 90 di sua lunghezza divenuta tonda.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Poi, come gente stata sotto larve, 92 che pare altro che prima, se si sveste 93 la sembianza non süa in che disparve,
94 così mi si cambiaro in maggior feste 95 li fiori e le faville, sì ch’io vidi 96 ambo le corti del ciel manifeste.
query.result:
91 Then, as people having been under larvae, 92 who seem other than before, if they undress 93 the appearance not his in which disappeared,
94 thus they changed themselves to me in greater feast 95 the flowers and the sparks, so that I saw 96 both the courts of the manifest sky.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 O isplendor di Dio, per cu’ io vidi 98 l’alto trïunfo del regno verace, 99 dammi virtù a dir com’ ïo il vidi!
100 Lume è là sù che visibile face 101 lo creatore a quella creatura 102 che solo in lui vedere ha la sua pace.
query.result:
97 O splendor of God, by which I saw 98 the high triumph of the true kingdom, 99 grant me virtue to say how I saw it!
100 Light is up there that makes visible 101 the creator to that creature 102 who only in him seeing has his peace.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 E’ si distende in circular figura, 104 in tanto che la sua circunferenza 105 sarebbe al sol troppo larga cintura.
query.result: 103 It is so stretched in circular figure, 104 so much that its circumference 105 would to the sun be too wide a belt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Fassi di raggio tutta sua parvenza 107 reflesso al sommo del mobile primo, 108 che prende quindi vivere e potenza.
query.result: 106 You make of ray all its appearance 107 reflected at the summit of the first mobile, 108 which then takes life and power.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 E come clivo in acqua di suo imo 110 si specchia, quasi per vedersi addorno, 111 quando è nel verde e ne’ fioretti opimo,

query.result:
109 And as I climb in the water of its lowest 110 it mirrors itself, almost to see itself adorned, 111 when it is in the green and in the ripe little flowers,
112 yes, surpassing the light around around, 113 I saw it mirror in more than a thousand thresholds 114 as much of us up there made has return.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 E se l’infimo grado in sé raccoglie 116 sì grande lume, quanta è la larghezza 117 di questa rosa ne l’estreme foglie!
118 La vista mia ne l’ampio e ne l’altezza 119 non si smarriva, ma tutto prendeva 120 il quanto e ’l quale di quella allegrezza.
query.result:
115 And if the lowest degree in itself gathers 116 so great light, how great is the breadth 117 of this rose in the extreme leaves!
118 My sight in the wide and in the height 119 did not get lost, but took all 120 the how much and the which of that cheerfulness.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Presso e lontano, lì, né pon né leva: 122 ché dove Dio sanza mezzo governa, 123 la legge natural nulla rileva.
query.result: 121 Near and far, there, neither put nor lever: 122 because where God without middle governs, 123 the natural law reveals nothing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.

124 In the yellow of the everlasting rose, 125 which degrades and dilates and reddens 126 odor of praise to the sun that always springs,
127 as is he who is silent and wants to speak, 128 Beatrice drew me, and said: «Look 129 how great is the convent of the white robes!
130 See our city how much it turns; 131 see our benches so filled, 132 that few people more are desired there.

query.prompt:

query.result:

136 will sit the soul, which will be august, 137 of the high Henry, who to straighten Italy 138 will come first that it be arranged.
